summary.text:
The WebContainer Public API allows you build custom applications on top of an in-browser Node.js runtime.

Its main entrypoint is the

This type is in a separate module so that localservice can import it
without bundling all the other webcontainer specific stuff.
The main export of this library. An instance of

represents a runtime
ready to be used.
Gives access to the underlying file system.
environment variable for processes started through
The full path to the working directory (see
Mounts a tree of files into the filesystem. This can be specified as a tree object (

)
or as a binary snapshot generated by [
A tree of files, or a binary snapshot. Note that binary payloads will be transferred.
Specifies a nested path where the tree should be mounted.
events, which are emitted when a port is opened or closed by some process.

events, emitted when a running server is listening for incoming
connections and ready to answer requests.
events, emitted when a preview sends a
events, emitted when an internal error is triggered.
The command-line arguments for the program.
Spawns a process without command-line arguments.

Destroys the WebContainer instance, turning it unusable, and releases its resources. After this,
a new WebContainer instance can be obtained by calling

.

All entities derived from this instance (e.g. processes, the file system, etc.) also become unusable
after calling this method.

Boots a WebContainer. Only a single instance of WebContainer can be booted concurrently
(see

).

Booting WebContainer is an expensive operation.

Module to authenticate users. Once authenticated, the WebContainer instance
can fetch private packages to which the user has access.

If you use this module, you should call

once at application initialization time.
If you do server side rendering, it should be called on any page that uses the API.

The AuthAPI uses OAuth 2.0 with PKCE and reads parameters from the URL:

 -

:  This contains the OAuth code needed to get credentials.
 -

: This contains an error message if authentication fails.
            Typically, if the user declines the authorization.
Intialize the authentication for use in WebContainer.
Options to initialize the authentication of users.

Returns a promise that resolves when the user authorized your application.
This promise is guaranteed to never be rejected.

If the user never authorizes or declines your application, this promise never
resolves.

### Example:
Logout the user and clear any credentials that were saved locally.
is set and the revocation failed, the locally-saved credentials are discarded nonetheless.
Listens for 'logged-out' events, which are emitted when the credentials are revoked, meaning the user needs to re-authenticate.
Listens for 'auth-failed' events, which are emitted when the user declines authorization in another tab / popup.

This starts the OAuth flow, redirecting the current page to the
StackBlitz editor to authenticate the user.
is set to true, then instead of redirecting the current page, a popup is opened.

Authentication error used when authentication fails, likely because the user refused to grant
access or because they don't have permission.
A detailed description of the error.
A short description of the error.
The client id for this OAuth application.

header
used to load your application.

Choosing 'none' will result in no cross-origin isolation headers being used. This will only work on Chromium-based
browsers as long as an Origin Trial is supported.

This value is fixed the first time a WebContainer is booted, and cannot be changed in successive reboots.

For more info about cross-origin isolation, see our

Whether errors occurring in preview iframes on the current page should be forwarded
to the parent page. Captured errors originate from:

If set to 'exceptions-only', 'console.error's are not forwarded.

see
The contents of the file, either as a UTF-8 string or as raw binary.
Interface to interact directly with the WebContainer filesystem. Modeled after

in Node.

File system operations exposed here are scoped to the working directory: a given folder predetermined at boot time.
All paths are resolved with respect to this working directory.
A simple, tree-like structure to describe the contents of a folder to be mounted.
Current working directory for the process, relative to the

of this instance (which

).

and the
stream will never produce any chunks.

The size of the attached terminal.

A promise for the exit code of the process.
An input stream for the attached pseudoterminal device.

A stream that receives all terminal output, including the stdout and stderr emitted by the spawned process
_and_ its descendants.

Can be disabled by setting
Represents the character encoding options available for encoding and decoding data in Node.js buffers.
The port on which the server is listening.
The new status of the port.
The url where the server can be accessed.
The message sent by a preview.
The port on which the readied server is listening.
The url where the server can be accessed.
This function reloads the provided iframe.
The timeout after which the preview is reset if it hasn't responded to the reload event.
